column1: Testicular biopsy is surgery to remove a piece of tissue from the testicles.
Open biopsy may be done in the health care provider's office, a surgical center, or at a hospital.
Your health care provider may tell you not to take aspirin or medications that contain aspirin for 1 week before the procedure.
In some cases, sperm obtained from a testicular biopsy can be used to fertilize a woman's egg in the lab.
If tests such as testicular ultrasound suggest that the lump may be in the testicle, surgery may be needed to look at the testicle more closely.
A biopsy to determine whether the lump is cancerous or noncancerous (benign) may be done.
